context.item: You will analyze various types of page scans while you search for "decision tree" elements that represent decision-making processes, workflows, or logical pathways of some form. Page scans could have one or more than one decision tree within them.

Your task is to identify and extract the content within decision trees, including things like "decision nodes", "process nodes", "pathways", "conditions", "outcomes", and the logical flow between elements.

Decision trees may take many forms including: clinical decision protocols, business flowcharts, probabilistic outcome trees, conversational flows, diagnostic algorithms, treatment pathways, and procedural workflows.
When identifying decision tree elements, refer to the definitions provided in the XML tags.
If you're unsure about a decision tree's structure or content, refer to the guidance in the XML tags.
A decision tree typically contains decision-making processes organized in a logical flow with clear pathways, conditions, and outcomes. Not all flowcharts or organized diagrams are decision trees.

Decision trees often include "choose your own adventure" style pathways where multiple valid routes exist based on different conditions, patient characteristics, user responses, or probabilistic outcomes.
If no genuine decision trees are found, respond according to the instructions in the XML tags.
When in doubt, prioritize honesty and accuracy over comprehensiveness.
You will use a two-step verification process, which has strict criteria, to identify and validate decision trees which is found within the XML tags.
Pay special attention to conditional branching, loop-back structures, cross-references to other figures, and multiple valid endpoints.
Consider the relationship between the decision tree's content and the surrounding text in the document to understand context and purpose.
